(+33)72442852 (Received May 1, 1993; accepted August 10, 1993) Abstract 179 The synthesis, characterization and catalytic properties of new materials obtained by reaction of organometallic complexes of groups IIb, IVs, and VIa with the surface of metallic particles are reviewed. Two types of materials may be obtained by surface organometallic chemistry on metals: metal particles covered with organometallic fragments, and bimetallic particles of predetermined composition. Characterization of the organometallic fragments on the metal particles has demonstrated their thermal stability. These particles covered with surface organometallic fragments are new catalytic materials, highly selective in several reactions such as the hydrogenation of a,ss-unsaturated aldehydes, ethyl pyruvate, nitrobenzene, acrylonitrile, and olefins. The bimetallic particles without organometallic fragments are also highly active and selective for a variety of reactions such as hydrogenolysis of various alkanes and hydrogenolysis of esters. For these systems, the concept of "site isolation" has been advanced to account for the high selectivity of the reactions. Key words: bimetallic catalysts; custom design; surface organometallic chemistry 1. Introduction Surface organometallic chemistry (SOMC) is a relatively new field of chemistry which deals with the reactivity of organometallic compounds with surfaces. SOMC differs from organometallic chemical vapour deposition (OMCVD) in that the reactions of SOMC result in less than monolayer coverage of the surface, whereas OMCVD is used to prepare multilayered materials for electronic applications [ 1 ] . Due to its "monolayer" character, SOMC has been used to prepare relatively well-defined supported metallic catalysts [ 2-5 ] . The SOMC approach is very general: the organometallic compounds may be complexes of main group elements, transition metals, lanthanides or 'Corresponding authors. 0304-5102/94/$07.00 1994 - Elsevier Science B.V. These can be grafted onto the surfaces of oxides (silica, alumina, zeolites, zirconia, etc.), carbon (diamond, graphite or charcoal) or metals. Recently, there has been increasing interest in the application of SOMC to the preparation of bimetallic catalysts [ 4,6 ] . There is a wide variety of possible structures for these bimetallic catalysts. Surface science has been very successful in identifying some of the concepts relevant to bimetallic materials, for example, formation of surface alloys, phase segregation at the surface, decoration of crystallographic sites by adatoms, site sensitive chemisorption and changes in electronic properties, surface diffusion, surface reconstructions, etc. However, careful studies of the reactivity of organometallic complexes towards metallic surfaces have revealed new aspects of the chemistry of bimetallic catalysts. Indeed, a new domain of surface organometallic chemistry on metals is slowly emerging. New fundamental rules of this chemistry are being progressively established, and new materials have been obtained which have no analogues in molecular chemistry, classical heterogeneous catalysis or surface science. In some cases, these new materials exhibit extremely high chemo- or regioselectivity in catalysis. We will show in this short review that the nature of these new catalytic materials depends very strongly on the reactivity of the organometallic compound with the metallic surface. SOMC/metals can yield a metallic surface covered with adatoms or surface organometallic fragments, or an "alloy" having the desired composition. An increase in activity and/or selectivity for a given catalytic reaction is frequently achieved by replacing a traditional (mono) metallic catalyst by a bimetallic one [ 7 ] . The origin of this enhancement is not fully understood at the present time. Classical theories attribute these properties to geometric (ensemble effects, "site isolation" effects) [8], or electronic (electronic influence of an adsorbed metal on the supported metal) [ 9 ] effects in the bimetallic materials. In our opinion, the effects must be considered in a much broader context of catalysis. Any reaction occurring on a metallic surface should involve, in at least one elementary step, a "surface organometallic fragment" in which one or several atoms of the substrate molecule are bonded to one or several atoms of the surface. Scheme 1 represents an organometallic fragment (R-M= ) bound to a surface (X,Y); it is clear that the atomic composition of the surface, especially one with bimetallic character, will influence the reactivity of the surface organometallic fragment. While the role of the two metals can be attributed to either a geometric effect [8] or an electronic effect [9,10] of the second metal on the first one, bimetallic catalysts have to be perfectly homogeneous and precise in composition on an atomic scale. SOMC/M is one possible way to achieve such homogeneity, because high temperature treatments can usually be avoided. The strategy of SOMC/M is to utilize "controlled" surface reactions, in which the transformation of monometallic materials into homogeneous bimetallic ones is understood in terms of molecular processes. The monometallic catalyst is first prepared, giving a relatively well-defined metallic surface, which is then allowed to react with an organometallic molecule, the precursor of the second metal in the bimetallic product. Previous attempts at this chemistry [ 11,12 ] involved grafting a group IV or VI metal (e.g., Sn, Ge, Pb, Mo) onto an oxide surface to create the host surface. The metal-modified oxide was then treated with a group VIII organometallic compound (e.g., n-allyl nickel, bis-7r-metallyl platinum). However, the monometallic support was not always very well defined, and therefore the SOMC reaction could not be easily monitored. It is well-known that well-defined group VIII metal particles supported on oxides can be prepared in a fully reduced form. These reduced metallic surfaces are perfect "host" surfaces and their use as such will be considered here. The nature of the organic moiety surrounding the organometallic molecule is of great importance in controlling surface reactions. Numerous studies of metal carbonyl complexes have been reported [ 6 ] . However, the reaction of carbonyl complexes with the surfaces of metals inevitably leads to evolution of CO, which is known to poison metallic sites. In 1984, Travers [ 13 ] , Margitfalvi [ 14 ] , and Nuzzo [ 15 ] simultaneously described new preparative routes for bimetallic particles by the reaction of a group IVs alkylmetal compound with a supported metallic surface of Rh, Pt or Ni. We have approached this chemistry by considering at an atomic or a molecular level the chemistry involved in the grafting reaction. We first discovered that the surface reaction strongly depends on whether the surface is oxidised or reduced [ 16 ] . The most reproducible results are obtained when the surface is fully reduced. In this review, we describe the reaction between the metallic surfaces of reduced group VIII metals and alkyl complexes of group II, III, IV and VI metals. Precise control of the reaction between the organometallic complex and the surface of the "host" metal arises from knowledge of the complete reaction path which governs the geometry and orientation of the incoming molecules, as well as the chemical state of the bimetallic catalyst. 2. Preparation and characterisation of monometallic catalysts The strategy of SOMC/metals requires first the preparation of monometallic catalysts. Si02, Zr02 and A1203 have all been used as support materials. In our laboratory, surface organometallic chemistry of tin and germanium on silica is quite well understood [ 17 ] , and it is therefore feasible to determine whether the organometallic complex reacts on the metallic phase, on the silica support, or both. Determination of such selectivity in SOMC is achieved using solid state NMR among other techniques. Supported group VIII metals can be prepared using conventional ion-ex- change methods followed by H2 reduction (Rh/Si02 [18], Rh/Zr02 [19], Ni/ Si02 [20], Pt/A1203 [21] ) or by the surface organometallic chemistry route (Ru/Si02 [22] ). These monometallic systems have been fully characterised by various physical techniques (e.g., electron microscopy, XPS, EXAFS, Xray diffraction) and by the selective chemisorption of hydrogen. Characterization of the bimetallic surface organometallic complexes, M[M' Rjy/oxide Thorough characterization of the bimetallic catalysts is a prerequisite to the rational design of catalysts for industrial processes. It is important to know the chemical state of the two types of metal atoms, as described by their oxidation states, ligand environments, structure and stoichiometry. EXAFS can be particularly useful for structural characterization of the bimetallic organometallic catalyst. For example, Didillon et al. [30] applied EXAFS at the Sn K-edge to the analysis of [Rh.Sn(n-C4H9)2/SiO2 (x=2, y=1) ] . The Fourier transform EXAFS data are consistent with an average of two light atoms (C or O) at 0.217 nm and 2 heavy atoms (Rh or Sn) at 0.268 nm in the primary coordination sphere of the Sn atom. Conclusion In the course of this short review article, we have considered various aspects of SOMC/M. The first conclusion that can be drawn is that the relevant metal particles are able to react with a variety of organometallic complexes to give a new material in which some organometallic fragments can bind to the particle. This is an unexpected result. In several cases, the organometallic fragment is thermally stable up to fairly high temperatures. Characterisation of the organometallic fragment grafted to the surface of the metal particle has been achieved and there is now ample evidence to demonstrate such phenomena. The fact that a thermally and chemically stable organometallic fragment can be grafted at the surface of a metal particle opens a new field of investigation in heterogeneous catalysis by metals. As a demonstration of this potential, several catalytic reactions (hydrogenation of citral to geraniol and nerol, hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to aniline, etc.) become much more selective when a metallic surface is derivatised with an organometallic fragment. It has been clearly established that even after catalysis, the organometallic fragment remains on the surface. The role of the organometallic fragment, while not yet 202 J.-P. Candy et al. / J. Mol. Catal. 86 (1994)179-204 completely understood, is its ability to impart to the catalyst a chemical specificity, such as regio- chemo- or stereo-selectivity, hydrophilicity, hydrophobicity, etc. The subject is just beginning to be explored fully. The organometallic preparative route also gives remarkable results for another class of material, the well-defined "alloys" of predetermined composition. Such "alloys" are also important catalysts for a wide variety of reactions. In these "alloys", the active transition metal is apparently surrounded by inactive main group elements, leading to the simple concept of "site isolation". These isolated sites lead to high selectivities in several reactions such as hydrolysis of alkanes or esters. There is no doubt that this new field of heterogeneous catalysts prepared by surface organometallic chemistry on metals to give alloys, is also slowly emerging. There are still some technological problems to overcome before these new materials can be applied on an industrial scale, but the exceptionally high degree of selectivity obtained will certainly be a driving force to overcome difficulties in the science of catalyst preparation. The synthesis, characterization and catalytic properties of new materials obtained by reaction of organometallic complexes of groups IIb, IVa, and VIa with the surface of metallic particles are reviewed. Two types of materials may be obtained by surface organometallic chemistry on metals: metal particles covered with organometallic fragments, and bimetallic particles of predetermined composition. Characterization of the organometallic fragments on the metal particles has demonstrated their thermal stability. These particles covered with surface organometallic fragments are new catalytic materials, highly selective in several reactions such as the hydrogenation of α,β-unsaturated aldehydes, ethyl pyruvate, nitrobenzene, acrylonitrile, and olefins. The bimetallic particles without organometallic fragments are also highly active and selective for a variety of reactions such as hydrogenolysis of various alkanes and hydrogenolysis of esters. For these systems, the concept of “site isolation” has been advanced to account for the high selectivity of the reactions.
